content.question:
As a first step in developing a new drug to treat cancer in humans, an initial study of the drug is undertaken in rats. Three hundred rats with cancer are studied, and each is assigned to one of three treatments. One hundred rats are randomly assigned to a high dose of the new drug, 100 are randomly assigned to a low dose, and 100 are randomly assigned to a control group (no drug). After six months, each rat is examined and classified as having developed no tumors, one tumor, or two or more tumors.
Which of the following would be an appropriate alternative hypothesis in this study for a chi-square test for homogeneity of tumor response across treatments?

choices.label: <math alttext="H sub a:" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow></msub><mtext> </mtext><mo>:</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> There is no difference in the distribution of tumor status across the three treatments.

<math alttext="H sub a:" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow></msub><mtext> </mtext><mo>:</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> There is a difference in the distribution of tumor status across the three treatments.

<math alttext="H sub a:" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow></msub><mtext> </mtext><mo>:</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> There is no association between tumor status and treatment.

<math alttext="H sub a:" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow></msub><mtext> </mtext><mo>:</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> There is an association between tumor status and treatment.

<math alttext="H sub a:" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow></msub><mtext> </mtext><mo>:</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> The proportion of rats with no tumors is the same for each treatment group.

content.answer: <math alttext="H sub a:" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow></msub><mtext> </mtext><mo>:</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> There is a difference in the distribution of tumor status across the three treatments.
